questions.text:
Match the following curves to show the plasma effect with the corresponding insulins.

(Here, B indicates breakfast, L lunch, S supper, and HS bedtime. An upward arrow shows insulin administration at mealtime)

 Column A

  1. Yellow curve
  2. Red curve
  3. Green curve
  4. Dotted blue curve

 

Column B

  1. Insulin Glulisine
  2. Insulin Glargine
  3. NPH Insulin
  4. Regular Insulin
  5. Continuous Infusion Insulin Pump
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d.

Yellow curve NPH insulin
Red curve Insulin glulisine  
Green curve Insulin glargine  
Dotted blue curve Regular insulin

 

Panel A shows the administration of long-acting Insulin glargine (green curve) to provide basal insulin and a premeal short-acting insulin analog (red curve).

Panel B shows a twice-daily injection of NPH insulin providing basal insulin (yellow curve) and regular insulin (dotted curve) or insulin analog (red curve) providing mealtime insulin coverage. Note that only one type of short-acting insulin would be used.

The insulin level attained following subcutaneous insulin (short-acting insulin analog) by an insulin pump programmed to deliver different basal rates would appear as below:

Related Pearl: Insulin Classification According to Duration of Action

Inhaled insulin (2-3 hours)

  • Afrezza 

Rapid acting (3-4 hours)

  • Aspart
  • Glulisine
  • Lispro

Short acting (6-8 hours)

  • Regular

Intermediate acting (10-16 hours)

  • NPH
  • Lente

Long acting (12-24 hours)

  • Detemir
  • Glargine
  • Degludec (24-42 hours)

questions.text:
Match the following:
1 - Kleptomania A - Intense desire to drink alcoholic drinks
2 - Pyromania B - Intense desire to mutilate
3 - Mutilomania C - Intense desire to steal items of trivial value
4 - Dipsomania D - Intense desire to burn things
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

Impulse control disorders are characterized by the repeated failure to resist an impulse, drive, or urge to perform an act that is rewarding to the person, at least in the short-term, despite consequences such as long-term harm either to the individual or to others; marked distress about the behavior pattern; or significant impairment in personal, family, social, educational, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

It includes

  1. Pyromania
  2. Kleptomania 
  3. Compulsive sexual behavior disorder
  4. Intermittent explosive disorder

Kleptomania is the repeated failure to resist impulses to steal objects that are of no value to the person. The individual can usually afford the object or does not need it, but it is the act of stealing itself that is the goal. The stolen objects are usually given away, returned, or kept hidden. The act is not planned and is carried out alone.

Pyromania is the deliberate setting of fires on more than one occasion. 

Pyromania is significantly associated with the following:

  • Substance abuse disorder (especially alcoholism).
  • Affective disorders (depression or bipolar)
  • Other impulse control disorders, such as kleptomania in female firesetters.
  • Personality disturbances, such as borderline personality disorders.
  • Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder and learning disabilities in childhood pyromania.

Dipsomania is an irresistible impulse to drink alcohol at a periodic intervals.

Mutilomania is an irresistible impulse to mutilate animals.

questions.text: Match the following intracranial bleed:

choices.text: A -i B-ii C- iii  D- iv

questions.solution:
Epidural hematoma:

Noncontrasted axial computed tomography scan showing a lenticular area of increased density in left parietal region.

  • Typically occur in the groove of the middle meningeal artery associated with temporal bone fractures that have resulted in a tear of middle meningeal artery.
  • They tend to not to cross suture lines of the skull.

Subdural hematoma:

A non contrasted computed tomography scan of acute subdural hematoma shows a cresentric area of increased density in the right posterior parietal region between brain and the skull. An area of intraparenchymal haemorrhage also seen. In addition, mass effect causes a midline shift to left.

  • They can cross suture lines but they do not cross the tentorium or falx.
  • Can be acute or chronic

Subarachnoid haemorrhage:

A non contrasted axial computed tomography scan shows the blood as areas of increased density near the base of the brain shows blood in Texaco star pattern formed blood radiating from suprasellar cistern into the sylvian fissures and anterior interhemispheric fissure.

  • Most often accompanied by severe sudden onset headache.
  • Can really be visualised in acute stage, when blood is radiographically dense (whiter) than the CSF.

Intracereberal haemorrhage:

Non contrast computed tomography shows a large area of fresh blood appearing white in the region of right thalamus. Blood is denser than CSF so settles dependently.

This settling is not seen with subarachnoid or interparenchymal blood.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text:
Match the following specialized macrophages with the tissues they are found in.
Cell Tissue
I. Hofbauer cells A. Kidney
II. Histiocytes  B. Placenta 
III. Kupffer cells  C. Connective tissue 
IV. Microglia D. Liver 
V. Mesangial cells  E. Brain
questions.solution:
The correct answer is I-B; II-C; III-D; IV-E; V-A.

Cell  Tissue 
I. Hofbauer cells B. Placenta 
II. Histiocytes  C. Connective tissue 
III. Kupffer cells  D. Liver 
IV. Microglia E. Brain
V. Mesangial cells  A. Kidney

Macrophages can be divided into:

1. Blood macrophages (monocytes) are the largest of the myeloid cells found in the peripheral blood. They survive for 3 days. 
2. Tissue macrophages present in different organs. They survive for months. 
The main functions of macrophages are phagocytosis and antigen presentation.

The specialised (tissue-specific) macrophages present in different tissues are listed below: 

  1. Peripheral blood: Monocytes
  2. Placenta: Hofbauer cells
  3. Liver: Kupffer cells
  4. Brain: Microglial cells
  5. Kidney: Mesangial cells
  6. Lungs: Alveolar macrophages
  7. Bone: Osteoclasts
  8. Connective tissue: Histiocytes

questions.text:
Match the following fetal structures with their corresponding adult structures:
A.Umbilical vein  1.Ligamentum venosum
B.Ductus venosus  2.Ligamentum teres
C.Umbilical artery  3.Ligamentum arteriosum
D.Ductus arteriosus  4.Medial umbilical ligament
questions.solution:
The correct option is A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3.

The vessels that are occluded soon after birth are in due course replaced by fibrous tissue and forms the following ligaments:

Fetal structure Adult structure
Foramen ovale Fossa ovalis
Umbilical vein Ligamentum teres
Ductus venosus Ligamentum venosum
Umbilical arteries Medial umbilical ligaments
Ductus arteriosus Ligamentum arteriosum

The median umbilical ligament or Xander's ligament represents the remnant of the embryonic urachus.

The lateral umbilical ligaments are folds of the peritoneum over the inferior epigastric arteries.

The umbilical vein is the preferred vessel for an isovolumetric and simultaneous double set up exchange transfusion. The obliterated remnant of the umbilical vein is the Ligamentum teres.

Related Pearl: Remnants of Various Embryonic Parts of the Cardiovascular System

Embryonic part

Remnants

Ductus arteriosus

Ligamentum arteriosum

Umbilical artery

Proximal part: Superior vesical artery; Distal part: Medial umbilical ligament

Umbilical vein (left)

Ligamentum teres

Ductus venosus

Ligamentum venosum

Septum primum

Floor of fossa ovalis

Septum secundum

Lower free edge: Annulus ovalis

 curved upper Margin: limbus fossa ovalis

questions.text:
Match the following vaccines with their respective route of administration:

 

Vaccine

 Route
1. Pneumococcal conjugate  A.Oral
2. BCG  B.Subcutaneous
3. JE C.Intradermal
4. Rotavirus D.Intramuscular
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A.

BCG is intradermally administered.

Hepatitis B vaccine, Pentavalent vaccine, along with DPT, Pneumococcal conjugate Vaccine, and the tetanus toxoid are administered via the intramuscular route. 

OPV and Rotaviral vaccines are administered orally.

The vaccines that are administered subcutaneously are Measles/Rubella vaccine and the JE vaccine.

questions.text:
Match the following patient descriptions with the ASA Category that they are likely to fall under -
  Patient description   ASA Category
1. A 70-year-old male patient with ESRD undergoing regular dialysis A. ASA V
2. A 23-year-old primigravida at 24-weeks gestation B. ASA III
3. A 55-year-old male patient who had an MI 2 months previously C. ASA VI
4. A 66-year-old male patient with a large ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm D. ASA II
    E. ASA IV
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-B, 2-D, 3-E, 4-A.

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

Class Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

questions.text:
Match the following visual field defects with the likely site of the lesion -
  1. Right superior homonymous quadrantopia
  2. Right sided homonymous hemianopia
  3. Right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing
  4. Right inferior quadrantic hemianopia
  5. Left-sided complete anopia
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-B, 3-E, 4-D, 5-A

Lesion site Fibers affected Visual defect
A - Lesion in left optic nerve Left nasal and left temporal fibers affected 5. Left-sided complete anopia
B - Lesion in left optic tract Left temporal and right nasal fibers affected 2. Right-sided homonymous hemianopia
C - Lesion in left Meyer's loop Left inferior temporal and right inferior nasal fibers affected

1. Right superior homonymous quadrantanopia (Pie in the sky) 
D - Lesion in left Baum's loop Left superior temporal and right superior nasal fibers affected 4. Right inferior homonymous quadrantanopia (Pie in the floor)
E - Lesion in left visual cortex sparing the macula Left temporal and right nasal fibers except the macular fibers 3. Right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing

 

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text:
Match the following slides of the causative organisms with their systemic mycosis.

             I. Valley fever

            II. Darling's disease

           III. Brazilian blastomycosis 

            IV. North American blastomycosis
questions.solution:
The correct answer is a-II, b-IV, c-I, d-III

a- Histoplasma II- Darling's disease
b- Blastomyces IV- North American blastomycosis
c- Coccidioides I- Valley fever
d- Para-coccidioidomycosis III- Brazilian blastomycosis 

Slide-a shows tiny oval yeast cells with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response suggestive of Histoplasma capsulatum that causes histoplasmosis/ Darling's disease/ reticuloendotheliosis.

Patients present with fever, cough, anorexia, and lymphadenopathy. X-ray of the chest shows focal infiltrates and patchy opacities. Aspiration from lymph nodes shows the presence of intracellular yeast.

Slide-b showing thick-walled round yeast cells with single broad-based budding depicting the figure of 8 appearance is suggestive of Blastomyces dermatitidis that causes North American blastomycosis. 

It is mostly seen in North America and is contracted through the inhalation of contaminated soil. Primary infection usually presents as pneumonia.  Chest X-ray reveals consolidation. Disseminated disease may lead to multiple abscesses. Cutaneous lesions present as papules and nodules which progress into large ulcerative lesions.

Slide-c showing mature spherules which are large sac-like structures filled with endospores is suggestive of Coccidioides immitis that causes Valley Fever.

Patients present with fever, cough, and severe fatigue. They may complain of night sweats and pleuritic chest pain. Chest X-ray shows mediastinal lymphadenopathy. It is most commonly seen in travelers to the southwestern USA.

Slide-d showing round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferentially giving rise to mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance is suggestive of Paracoccidioidomycosis brasiliensis that causes Brazilian blastomycosis/ South American blastomycosis/ Paracoccidioidal granuloma.

Patients present with fever, fatigue, and weight loss. On examination, multiple oral lesions and hepatosplenomegaly are noted. Granulomas are seen on a biopsy of the affected tissues.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: Match the following

choices.text: 1 - Deaver's retractor; 2 - Morris  retractor; 3 - Doyen's  retractor; 4 - Czerney's  retractor
1 - Deaver's  retractor; 2 - Doyen's  retractor; 3 - Morris  retractor; 4 - Czerney's  retractor
1 - Czerney's  retractor; 2 - Deaver's  retractor; 3 - Morris  retractor; 4 - Deaver's  retractor
1 - Czerney's  retractor; 2 - Deaver's  retractor; 3 - Doyen's  retractor; 4 - Morris  retractor

questions.solution:
The correctly matched options are 1 - Deaver's retractor; 2 - Doyen's retractor; 3 - Morris retractor; 4 - Czerney's retractor

Deaver’s Retractor is specifically designed for holding the liver up out of the way during a cholecystectomy. It needs to be used carefully to avoid damaging the liver.

Doyen's retractor - It is used to pull back the soft tissues and widen the surgical field during laparotomy.

Morris Retractor is a big retractor which is useful for giving maximum exposure in large incisions such as those used in the abdomen. It can be used to improve visibility on one side of an incision (by pulling firmly in that direction); so is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy.

Czerney's retractor - has two spikes on one end and a broad surface on the other. To facilitate insertion of the first mass closure stitch during closure of a midline laparotomy wound by retracting the superior or inferior edges.

 

Related Pearl: Identification of Surgical Retractors

Deaver's Retractor:

Doyen's retractor:

Morris retractor:

Czerny’s retractor:

questions.text:
Match the following metabolic derangements with their most likely presentations -
  Metabolic derangement   Clinical presentation
A. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency 1. Splenomegaly, avascular necrosis, and delayed puberty
B. Beta-galactosidase deficiency 2. Copious nasal discharge, corneal clouding, dysostosis multiplex
C. Alpha-L-iduronidase deficiency 3. Hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, doll-like facies
D. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase 4. Extreme irritability, developmental delay, optic atrophy
    5. Hepatomegaly, vomiting, cataracts, and sepsis
questions.solution:
The correct match is A-3, B-4, C-2, and D-5.

A. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is seen in Von Gierke disease which is a glycogen storage disorder (Type Ia). Patients with GSD Type I present with a protruding abdomen due to hepatomegaly, doll-like facies, hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, organomegaly, seizures, and pulmonary hypertension. It is an autosomal recessive disorder 

B. Beta-galactosidase deficiency is seen in Krabbe's disease which is a lysosomal storage disorder. It is an autosomal recessive disorder that results from the deficiency of galactocerebrosidase. The classic manifestations that would suggest Krabbe's disease include irritability, seizures, and hypertonia.  Optic atrophy and developmental delay are other features.

C. Alpha-L-iduronidase deficiency is seen in Hurler syndrome,  a type of mucopolysaccharidosis type I.  Infants develop characteristic coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, inguinal hernias, and typical skeletal abnormalities, known as dysostosis multiplex. Corneal clouding, short stature, and copious nasal discharge are other features.

D. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency is seen in classical galactosemia. Clinical features include jaundice, vomiting, hepatomegaly, and sepsis. They also tend to develop cataracts.

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

Related Pearl: Glycogen Storage Diseases

Severe fasting hypoglycemia

Growth failure

Lactic acidosis

Hyperuricemia

Hyperlipidemia

GSD type Ib

Endoplasmic reticulum glucose-6- phosphate transporter

Same as Von Gierke's disease

Recurrent infections due to impaired neutrophil function

GSD type II

Pompe's disease

Lysosomal α1,4:1,6 glucosidase

(Acid maltase)

Muscle weakness

Death by age ~ 2 years (infantile variant)

Cardiomegaly and heart failure

GSD type III

Cori's/Forbes disease

(Limit dextrinosis)

Glycogen debranching enzyme

Muscle weakness

Fasting hypoglycemia

Hepatomegaly due to accumulation of branched-chain polysaccharide (limit dextrins)

Growth retardation

Normal lactate and uric acid levels

GSD type IV

Andersen disease

Glycogen branching enzyme

Failure to thrive

Hepatomegaly due to accumulation of polysaccharides with few branch points

Death at age ~ 5 years

GSD type V

McArdle disease

Muscle glycogen phosphorylase

Exercise-induced cramps

Renal failure due to rhabdomyolysis and myoglobinuria

Second wind phenomenon

GSD type VI

Her's disease

Liver glycogen phosphorylase

Generally benign

Mild hypoglycemia

Hepatomegaly

GSD type VII

Tarui's disease

Muscle phosphofructokinase

Exercise-induced muscle cramps and weakness

Growth retardation

Hemolytic anemia

questions.text:
Match the following:
  1. First-degree heart block
  2. Mobitz type 1 heart block
  3. Mobitz type 2 heart block
  4. Complete heart block
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, and 4-b.

The different types of heart blocks are:

First Degree Heart Block: It occurs due to slowing of conduction through the AV junction. It is characterized by prolonged PR > 0.2s and equal RR intervals.

Second Degree Heart Block: It occurs due to the intermittent failure of electrical impulse conduction from the atrium to the ventricle. It is characterized by a missed QRS. It is of two types:

  • Mobitz type 1 (Wenckebach) occurs due to the decremental conduction of electrical impulses in the AV node. It is characterized by a progressive PR elongation leading to an eventual drop in the QRS complex. This may be seen in young athletes.
  • Mobitz type 2 occurs in the distal or infra-His conduction system and is often associated with intraventricular conduction delays. It is characterized by an intermittent failure of conduction of the p wave without any change in the preceding impulses. On ECG, there is a fixed PR interval and missed QRS.

Third Degree Heart Block/Complete Heart Block: It occurs when none of the impulses from the atria are conducted to the ventricles. It is characterized by

  • Escape rhythm
  • RR equal, PP equal
  • P waves > QRS waves
  • No relationship between P & QRS

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text:
Match the following:
1. I a. Inferior colliculus 
2. II b. Superior olivary complex
3. III c. The distal part of the cochlear nerve
4. IV d. Medial geniculate body
   e. Cochlear nucleus 
  f. The proximal part of the cochlear nerve
questions.solution:
The image shows a Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) tracing.

The correct match is:

1. I a.The distal part of the cochlear nerve  
2. II b.The proximal part of the cochlear nerve 
3. III c.cochlear nucleus 
4. IV d.superior olivary complex

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text:
Match the following Disorders of thought with the respective Classes:
Column A  Column B
1. Disorder of form a. Antisocial urges & Delusions
2. Disorder of stream b. Delusions & Thought echo
3. Disorder of possession c. Desultory thoughts & clang associations
4. Disorder of content d. Obsession & Compulsion
  e. Derailment & Word salad
  f. Flight of Ideas & Circumstantialities
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

1. Disorder of form e. Derailment and Word salad
2. Disorder of stream f. Flight of Ideas and Circumstantialities
3. Disorder of possession d. Obsession and Compulsion
4. Disorder of content a. Antisocial urges and Delusions

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

questions.text:
Match the following,
Column A Column B
1. A a. False Positive
2. B b. Positive predictive value
3. C c. True Negative
4. D d. Negative predictive value
  e. False Negative
  f. True Positive
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Column A Column B
1. A c. True Negative
2. B

e. False Negative
3. C

a. False Positive
4. D f. True Positive

 

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text:
Match the Following structure with their corresponding embryological origin:
Column A Column B
1. Stapes a. 6th pharyngeal arch
2. Arytenoid cartilages Intrinsic laryngeal muscles b. 3rd pharyngeal arch
3. Malleus and incus c. 2nd pharyngeal arch
4. Tympanic Membrane

 

 d. 1st pharyngeal arch
  e. Ectoderm and endoderm
  f. All 3 germ layers
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Column A Column B
1. Stapes c. 2nd pharyngeal arch
2. Arytenoid cartilages Intrinsic laryngeal muscles a. 6th pharyngeal arch
3. Malleus and incus d. 1st pharyngeal arch
4. Tympanic Membrane

 

 f. All 3 germ layers

 

Related Pearl: Embryology of the ear

Structures of the ear Embryological origin
Auricle or pinna 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arch
External auditory meatus 1st pharyngeal arch
Tympanic membrane All 3 germ layers
Malleus and incus 1st pharyngeal arch
Stapes suprastructure 2nd pharyngeal arch
Stapes footplate and annular ligament Otic capsule
Tympanic cavity 1st pharyngeal pouch
Eustachian tube 1st pharyngeal pouch
Membranous labyrinth Otic vesicle
Semicircular canals and utricle Pars superior
Saccule and cochlea Pars inferior

questions.text:
Match the following structures with their respective sites of opening:
Column A Column B
1. Nasolacrimal duct guarded by the valve of Hasner. a. Jacobson's organ
2. Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, and anterior ethmoidal sinus forming the Picadle’s circle b. Choana
3. Posterior ethmoidal sinus c. Nasopharynx
4. Auditory tube d. Superior meatus
  e. Inferior meatus
  f. Middle meatus
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Column A Column B
1. Nasolacrimal duct guarded by the valve of Hasner.

e. Inferior meatus
2. Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, and anterior ethmoidal sinus forming the Picadle’s circle f. Middle meatus
3. Posterior ethmoidal sinus d. Superior meatus
4. Auditory tube c. Nasopharynx

 

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus
